revision.text:
{{lead too short|date=August 2016}} {{Infobox video game | title = Painkiller: Resurrection | image = PK Resurrection.jpg | developer = HomeGrown Games | publisher = [[DreamCatcher Interactive]] (North America)
[[JoWooD Entertainment]] (Europe & Australia) | designer = | engine = PainEngine (with
[[Havok (software)|Havok]]) | released = {{vgrelease|NA|October 27, 2009|EU|November 6, 2009|AUS|February 25, 2010}} | genre = [[First-person shooter]], [[Action game|Action]] | modes = [[Single-player]], [[Multiplayer video game|multiplayer]] | platforms = [[Microsoft Windows]] }} '''''Painkiller: Resurrection''''' is a [[first-person shooter]] video game developed by Homegrown Games and published by [[DreamCatcher Interactive]] (now acquired by Nordic Games). It is a stand-alone expansion to the 2004 ''[[Painkiller (video game)|Painkiller]]'' developed by Homegrown Games, and runs on an updated version of PainEngine. It was released for [[Microsoft Windows]] in 2009. An [[Xbox 360]] version was also planned, but was cancelled. == Gameplay == ''Painkiller: Resurrection'' is based on a story game, compared to the other ''Painkiller'' games. The game's basic gameplay is similar to that of the original ''Painkiller'': the player has to face off numerous enemies and defeat them, moving from one location to another. All the weapons, as before, have alternative fire regimes. The slight difference in gameplay is this: the levels are large, with various paths and sections, which require the player to explore the environments between battles. Sometimes, minor objectives are given to player to accomplish. The main gameplay difference from the original game, is that the player most of the time can freely access the whole map, without waiting in one particular closed place, until all of the monsters will spawn; this enables a somewhat freedom of movement feeling and confusion as well, as often it will be unclear where to proceed next. This drastic change of gameplay is a questionable feature, because certain spawn and waypoint related bugs will appear due to that. The majority of enemies and all the original weapons are presented, and there is one new type of monster included. The game features some new additional gameplay elements not seen in original or its other expansions. This includes: * Only six levels (and 7th hidden level) * New protagonist with new phrases. * 2 new weapons (one of which was not made available until a later patch). * Voice of an ally, Elyahim, accompanies the player through his journey, giving advice and objectives. * The cutscenes are presented as a comic book similar in style to ''[[Max Payne (video game)|Max Payne]]''. == Plot == The story begins outside of the events depicted in other games and stars new protagonist: William "Bill" Sherman. Blown to pieces by his own [[C-4 (explosive)|C4]] payload, with which he wanted to eliminate a group of mobsters. The fact that he also accidentally blew up a bus full of innocent civilians has given rise to an all new problem - Hell doesn't exactly have any issues with claiming his soul. Now Bill's in purgatory and he's caught the eye of one of the Elyahim, the female spirits who guide the souls of men through purgatory. Guided by the Elyahim's voice, Bill, like Daniel Garner, is sent through this unholy realm to save his soul by destroying evil beings. After he defeats [[Aamon]], a monstrous dog demon, a greater demon appears, revealing himself to be [[Astaroth]], one of the generals of Lucifer. He asks Bill to join him, but Bill rejects. Surprisingly, Astaroth leaves Bill to continue his fight. After defeating a powerful spider-like demon, an angel, [[Ramiel]], appears, asking Bill to continue his fighting and clean the purgatory in exchange for a chance to return to life. Later, after more fighting through demons, Bill is greeted by Elyahim in person. She explains that Ramiel betrayed the Heaven and now he and Astaroth are planning to conquer the purgatory, so it could become their dominion. As Hell and Heaven are weakened, they would be able to claim all the new souls coming to the afterlife and soon become the most prominent force in the world. However, to do so, they needed Bill to eliminate the majority of demons, so none of them would reveal to Hell Astaroth's true motives. Now, Bill has to battle both of them at the same time. He kills Astaroth and wounds Ramiel, who begs him to spare his life. In exchange, Ramiel will return Bill back to Earth. From this points, the three endings are possible. *Good ending: Ramiel fulfills his promises and sends Bill back to life. Bill arrives a night before the incident happened. He takes the C4 off the car and throws it to the sea. Bill smiles, being happy for the first time. He decides to never return to killing again, understanding that the sole meaning of life is the life itself. *Bad ending: Ramiel fulfills his promises and sends Bill back to life. But it is all a trick, as Bill is sent to the exact moment he committed his greatest sin and died. Bill, again, tries to save the bus... but is killed again, this time being sent to Hell forever. *Neutral ending: Ramiel awaits Bill to agree to be sent back to life, but Elyahim appears. She warns Bill that the angel cannot be trusted as he has become corrupted. From her, Bill receives a holy sword: the only weapon with which a mortal could kill an angel. Bill strikes Ramiel and kills him. From now on, he is awarded by the heavens to be the ruler of the realm of purgatory. == Reception == {{Video game reviews | MC = 38/100{{cite web |url=http://www.metacritic.com/game/pc/painkiller-resurrection |title=Painkiller: Resurrection for PC Reviews |publisher=[[Metacritic]] |accessdate=May 28, 2016}} | GSpot = 3.5/10{{cite web |last=Todd |first=Brett |date=October 30, 2009 |url=http://www.gamespot.com/reviews/painkiller-resurrection-review/1900-6238488/ |title=Painkiller: Resurrection Review |publisher=[[GameSpot]] |accessdate=May 28, 2016}} | IGN = 2.6/10{{cite web |last=Onyett |first=Charles |date=November 9, 2009 |url=http://www.ign.com/articles/2009/11/09/painkiller-resurrection-review |title=Painkiller: Resurrection Review |publisher=[[IGN]] |accessdate=May 28, 2016}} | PCGUK = 56%{{cite journal |title=Painkiller: Resurrection |magazine=[[PC Gamer|PC Gamer UK]] |date=December 25, 2009 |page=116}} | PCZone = 19%{{cite journal |title=Painkiller: Resurrection |magazine=[[PC Zone]] |date=January 2010 |page=74}} }}{{expand section|date=August 2016}} The game received "unfavorable" reviews according to the [[Review aggregator|review aggregation]] website [[Metacritic]]. == References == {{reflist}} == External links == * {{moby game|id=/windows/painkiller-resurrection}} * [http://www.painkillergame.com/ http://www.painkillergame.com ''PainKiller'' video game series official website] * [http://www.pkzone.org/ http://www.pkzone.org/ — ''PainKiller'' video game series unofficial website] {{Painkiller series}} [[Category:2009 video games]] [[Category:Demon video games]] [[Category:First-person shooters]] [[Category:Video game sequels]] [[Category:Video games about angels]] [[Category:Video games based on mythology]] [[Category:Windows games]] [[Category:Windows-only games]] [[Category:Witchcraft in video games]] [[Category:Cancelled Xbox 360 games]] [[Category:Video game expansion packs]] [[Category:Video games developed in Austria]]

revision.comment: /* Details */ removed "man" from description and replaced with "person"
revision.text:
{{EngvarB|date=January 2017}} {{Use dmy dates|date=January 2017}} A '''pelican crossing''' (previously '''pelicon crossing''', which stood for "'''pe'''destrian '''li'''ght '''con'''trolled '''crossing'''") is a type of [[pedestrian crossing]], which features a pair of poles each with a standard set of [[traffic lights]] facing oncoming traffic, a push button and two illuminated, coloured pictograms facing the pedestrian from across the road. These are a red, stationary person to indicate that it is not safe to cross, and a green, walking person to indicate that it is safe to do so. Pelican crossings also provide non-visual indication that it is safe to cross, such as a beep, vibrating button or tactile rotating cone in order to assist [[Visual impairment|visually impaired]] pedestrians. Usage of pelican crossings is confined mainly to the UK, where they were invented, and in Ireland. A comparable system called the [[HAWK beacon]] is used in the United States.
==Details== [[File:20030614 08 Orpington High Street.jpg|thumb|200px|Pelican crossing, [[Orpington]] (2003)]] [[File:Green man panel.jpg|thumb|left|120px|A pelican crossing control panel]] [[File:Green man uk.jpg|thumb|200px|The "green person" signal]] The name is derived from ''PELICON'', a portmanteau of ''pe''destrian ''li''ght ''con''trolled. The term ''pelican crossing'' originated in the [[United Kingdom]], but similar traffic control devices are in use throughout the world. The term is also used in the [[Republic of Ireland]].
The pelican crossing was a relatively minor development of the "x–way" crossing. This earlier crossing was largely identical to the pelican crossing, but instead of a green light for motorists, featured a white diagonal cross. The intention of this was to distinguish the crossing lights from any nearby junction (standard) traffic lights). The white cross was widely criticised and users and motoring organisations alike called for the white cross to be replaced by a green light. With some changes to the light timings and road markings, the "x–way" crossing became the pelican crossing.
In the [[United Kingdom]], the pelican crossing was the first definitive light-controlled crossing for pedestrians, introduced in 1969. This was after the earlier failed experiment of the [[panda crossing]]. Previously only [[zebra crossing]]s had been used, which have warning signals ([[Belisha beacon]]s), but no control signals. The pedestrian lights are situated on the far side of the road to the pedestrian. A [[puffin crossing]] has the lights on the same side as the pedestrian; a [[toucan crossing]] is a crossing for pedestrians and [[bicycle]]s; a [[pegasus crossing]] allows horse riders to cross as well.
Additionally, a pelican crossing, as distinct from a puffin crossing, has the special feature that while the green person flashes to indicate that pedestrians may continue crossing but may not start to cross, the red light changes to an amber flashing light permitting cars to pass if there are no further pedestrians. This reduces the delay to traffic.
Under UK law{{citation needed|reason=|date=September 2015}}, pelican crossings that go straight across the road are defined as a single crossing, even when there is a central island. Therefore, traffic in both directions must wait until pedestrians have finished crossing and the signal is green or flashing amber. This rule is different from similar standard pedestrian crossings where each portion of the crossing is treated as a separate crossing. However, at installations where the crossings that cross each carriageway are separate crossings, the crossing is staggered.
In 1974, ''[[Dad's Army]]'' performed a [[public information film]] to explain the pelican crossing, and how it works.<ref>{{cite web|title=Pelican Crossing (Dad's Army) (1974)|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Z_AaiNL8H54|date=8 October 2009|accessdate=10 June 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Pelican Crossing-Motorist-Dads Army|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=BxRJvArUYwA|date=19 November 2009|accessdate=10 June 2015}}</ref> In 1976, [[Paul Greenwood]] sung "The Pelican Crossing Song", again explaining how a pelican crossing works. In 2000, [[Shooglenifty]] incorporated samples of a pelican crossing into their album ''[[Solar Shears]]''.
Statutory authority for pelican crossings was removed in the 2016 update of the [[Traffic Signs Regulations and General Directions]]. After 22 October 2016, no new pelican crossings can be installed on public highways in the UK, except work in progress where there was a six-month saving. Puffin crossings are to be installed instead. <ref name="TSGRD 2016">{{cite web |url=https://www.gov.uk/government/uploads/system/uploads/attachment_data/file/520872/DfT-circular-01-2016.pdf |title=DFT Circular 01/2016 - The Traffic Signs Regulations and General Directions 2016 |department=Department for Transport |page=63 section 17.6 |date=2015 |publisher= HMSO |access-date= 26 May 2018}}</ref>
===Internationally=== * In [[Hong Kong]], where control panels are also used as in the United Kingdom, no zig-zag lines are marked. At some crossings the traffic signals still turn to red; but at much longer intervals. * A [[HAWK beacon]], used with a standard pedestrian crossing signal, stops traffic when a pedestrian pushes a button to cross, but goes dark unless activated. It was allowed in experimental applications in the United States until 2009 and is now a standard option for transportation engineers. * [[British Columbia]], [[Canada]], indicates pedestrian-controlled crossings using flashing green signals.<ref>[http://www.icbc.com/driver-licensing/Getting-licensed/drivers3.pdf ICBC] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20131022032056/http://www.icbc.com/driver-licensing/Getting-licensed/drivers3.pdf |date=22 October 2013 }}, Chapter 3, page 9</ref> When a pedestrian activates the signal, the flashing green turns steady green, followed by yellow and red. When the crossing phase is complete, the signal returns to flashing green.
==See also== * [[Toucan crossing]] * [[Puffin crossing]] * [[Pegasus crossing]] * [[Zebra crossing]]
==References== {{reflist}} * ''The History of British Roadsigns'', Dept. for Transport, 2nd Edition, 1999.
==External links== *[http://news.bbc.co.uk/onthisday/hi/dates/stories/april/2/newsid_2840000/2840919.stm BBC article], on the introduction of Panda crossings, and subsequent developments.
{{Pedestrian crossings}}
[[Category:Pedestrian crossings]] [[Category:Road surface markings]] [[Category:Walking in the United Kingdom]]

revision.text:
{{pp-protected|reason=Persistent [[WP:Disruptive editing|disruptive editing]]|expiry=11:00, 20 February 2019|small=yes}} {{Redirect|Pirates 4|the 3D short film|Pirates 4-D|the soundtrack|Pirates of the Caribbean: On Stranger Tides (soundtrack)}} {{good article}} {{Use mdy dates|date=June 2016}} {{Infobox film | name = Pirates of the Caribbean:
On Stranger Tides | image = On Stranger Tides Poster.jpg | alt = The film's main character Jack Sparrow stands on a beach. He wears a red bandana, a dark blue vest with a white shirt underneath and black pants. Attached to his belt are two guns and a scarf. A ship with flaming sails is approaching from the sea. In the background, three mermaids are sitting on a rock. The names of the main actors are seen atop the poster, and the film credits are at the bottom. | caption = Theatrical release poster | director = [[Rob Marshall]] | producer = [[Jerry Bruckheimer]] | screenplay = {{Plain list| * [[Ted Elliott (screenwriter)|Ted Elliott]] * [[Terry Rossio]] }} | story = {{Plain list| * Ted Elliott * Terry Rossio }} | based on = {{Plain list| * {{Based on|''[[On Stranger Tides]]''|[[Tim Powers]]}} * {{Based on|[[List of Pirates of the Caribbean characters|Characters]]|Ted Elliott
Terry Rossio
[[Stuart Beattie]]
[[Jay Wolpert]]}} * {{Based on|[[Pirates of the Caribbean (attraction)|Pirates of the Caribbean]]|[[Walt Disney]]}} }} | starring = {{Plain list| * [[Johnny Depp]] * [[Penélope Cruz]] * [[Ian McShane]] * [[Kevin R. McNally]] * [[Geoffrey Rush]] }} | music = [[Hans Zimmer]] | cinematography = [[Dariusz Wolski]] | editing = {{Plain list| * [[David Brenner (editor)|David Brenner]] * Wyatt Smith }} | production companies = {{Plain list| * [[Walt Disney Pictures]] * Jerry Bruckheimer Films }} | distributor = [[Walt Disney Studios Motion Pictures|Walt Disney Studios
Motion Pictures]] | released = {{Film date|2011|05|07|[[Disneyland Resort]]|2011|5|20|United States}} | runtime = 137 minutes{{cite web|title=Pirates of the Caribbean: On Stranger Tides |url=http://bbfc.co.uk/releases/pirates-caribbean-stranger-tides-2011-6 |publisher=[[British Board of Film Classification]] |date=May 5, 2011 |accessdate=February 7, 2015 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160306023607/http://bbfc.co.uk/releases/pirates-caribbean-stranger-tides-2011-6 |archivedate=March 6, 2016 }} | country = United States | language = English | budget = {{ubl|$410.6 million (gross)|$378.5 million (net){{cite web|last=Sylt |first=Christian |title=Fourth Pirates Of The Caribbean Is Most Expensive Movie Ever With Costs Of $410 Million |url=https://www.forbes.com/sites/csylt/2014/07/22/fourth-pirates-of-the-caribbean-is-most-expensive-movie-ever-with-costs-of-410-million/ |work=[[Forbes]] |date=July 22, 2014 |accessdate=December 7, 2014 |quote=Production costs: $410.6 million; rebate: $32.1 million |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20141208004952/http://www.forbes.com/sites/csylt/2014/07/22/fourth-pirates-of-the-caribbean-is-most-expensive-movie-ever-with-costs-of-410-million/ |archivedate=December 8, 2014 }}}} | gross = $1.046 billion{{cite web|title=Pirates of the Caribbean: On Stranger Tides (2011) |url=http://boxofficemojo.com/movies/?id=piratesofthecaribbean4.htm |publisher=[[Box Office Mojo]] |accessdate=August 22, 2011 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130425015645/http://boxofficemojo.com/movies/?id=piratesofthecaribbean4.htm |archivedate=April 25, 2013 }} }} '''''Pirates of the Caribbean: On Stranger Tides''''' is a 2011 American [[Fantasy film|fantasy]] [[swashbuckler film]], the fourth installment in the [[Pirates of the Caribbean (film series)|''Pirates of the Caribbean'' film series]] and the sequel to ''[[Pirates of the Caribbean: At World's End|At World's End]]'' (2007). It is the first film in the series not to be directed by [[Gore Verbinski]], being replaced by [[Rob Marshall]]. [[Jerry Bruckheimer]] again served as producer. The film is technically a [[Sequel#Standalone sequels|stand-alone sequel]] to the previous installments. In the film, which draws its plot loosely from the novel ''[[On Stranger Tides]]'' by [[Tim Powers]], [[Jack Sparrow|Captain Jack Sparrow]] ([[Johnny Depp]]) is joined by [[Angelica (Pirates of the Caribbean)|Angelica]] ([[Penélope Cruz]]) in his search for the [[Fountain of Youth]], confronting the infamous pirate [[Blackbeard (Pirates of the Caribbean)|Blackbeard]] ([[Ian McShane]]). The film was produced by [[Walt Disney Pictures]] and released in the United States on May 20, 2011. It was the first film in the series to be released in the [[Disney Digital 3-D]] and [[IMAX 3D]] formats. Writers [[Ted Elliott (screenwriter)|Ted Elliott]] and [[Terry Rossio]] first learned of Powers' novel ''[[On Stranger Tides]]'' during the back-to-back production of ''[[Pirates of the Caribbean: Dead Man's Chest|Dead Man's Chest]]'' (2006) and ''[[Pirates of the Caribbean: At World's End|At World's End]]'', and considered it a good starting point for a new film in the series. Pre-production started after the end of the [[2007–2008 Writers Guild of America strike]], with Depp collaborating with the writers on the story design. [[Principal photography]] lasted for 106 days between June and November 2010, with locations in Hawaii, the United Kingdom, Puerto Rico and California. Filming employed [[3D film|3D]] cameras similar to those used in the production of the 2009 film ''[[Avatar (2009 film)|Avatar]]'', and ten companies were involved with the film's [[visual effects]]. Following inflated production costs which ballooned the net budget to $379 million, the film is currently regarded as the [[List of most expensive films|most expensive film ever made]]. ''On Stranger Tides'' broke many box office records upon release, was the [[2011 in film#Highest-grossing films|third highest-grossing film of 2011]], and it stands as the [[List of highest-grossing films|28th-highest-grossing film of all time worldwide]] when not adjusting for inflation. Critical reviews were mixed, with the film receiving criticism over its writing, directing, excessiveness and lack of originality; positive mentions were given on the acting, action sequences, music, visuals and the running time for being much shorter than the previous two films. A fifth film, titled ''[[Pirates of the Caribbean: Dead Men Tell No Tales|Dead Men Tell No Tales]]'', was released in 2017. ==Plot== After a failed attempt to rescue his first mate, [[Joshamee Gibbs]], in London, [[Jack Sparrow|Captain Jack Sparrow]] is brought before [[George II of Great Britain|King George II]]. The king wants Jack to guide an expedition to the [[Fountain of Youth]] before [[Ferdinand VI of Spain|King Ferdinand]] and the [[Spanish Navy]] can locate it. Jack's old nemesis, Captain [[Hector Barbossa]], now a [[privateer]] in service to the [[Royal Navy|British Navy]] after losing his leg and ship, the ''[[Black Pearl]]'', which he says was sunk, is heading the expedition. Jack refuses the offer and escapes. He meets up with his father, [[Captain Teague]], who warns Jack about the Fountain's rituals. Jack learns someone is impersonating him to recruit a crew to find the Fountain. The impostor is [[Angelica (Pirates of the Caribbean)|Angelica]], Jack's former lover, and the daughter of the ruthless pirate [[Blackbeard (Pirates of the Caribbean)|Blackbeard]], who practices [[Haitian Vodou|voodoo]] magic and wields the mythical "Sword of [[Triton (mythology)|Triton]]" that controls his ship, the ''[[Queen Anne's Revenge]]''. While Jack is [[Shanghaiing|shanghaied]] aboard Blackbeard's ship, Gibbs escapes execution by memorizing and destroying Jack's map showing the Fountain's location, forcing Barbossa to take him along. Meanwhile, after a failed [[mutiny]] aboard the ''Queen Anne's Revenge'', Jack is forced to guide the crew to the Fountain. Blackbeard seeks the Fountain's power to circumvent his predestined fatal encounter with a "one-legged man", who happened to be Barbossa. Jack must find two silver chalices aboard [[Juan Ponce de León]]'s missing [[flagship]], the ''Santiago''. The Fountain's water must simultaneously be drunk by two people from the chalices. Drinking from one chalice containing a [[mermaid]]'s tear will extend life; the second person dies, their remaining years of life transferred to the other drinker. Jack also discovers that the ''Black Pearl'' was captured and shrunk before being added to Blackbeard's collection of other shrunken [[Ship in a bottle|ships in bottles]]. The ''Queen Anne's Revenge'' heads for Whitecap Bay to find and harvest mermaid tears. After managing to lure in a mermaid named Tamara, she summons other mermaids to attack the crew before Jack causes an explosion that scares them away. A mermaid named Syrena is caught, but Philip Swift, a captive missionary, falls in love with her. Reaching Ponce de León's ship on an uncharted island, Angelica and Blackbeard coerce Jack into retrieving both chalices. Jack locates the grounded, decaying vessel, only to find Barbossa there. Both guess that the Spanish have taken the chalices, after they are nowhere to be found on the vessel. Jack and Barbossa team up to sneak into the Spanish camp and steal the chalices. Barbossa reveals he only wants revenge against Blackbeard for attacking the ''Black Pearl'', and his leg being amputated. Jack and Barbossa escape with the chalices. Meanwhile, Syrena, reciprocating Philip's love, is tricked into shedding a tear. Blackbeard collects it, leaving her to die of dehydration while Philip is forced to go with them. Jack returns with the chalices and bargains with Blackbeard for Angelica's safety, Jack's confiscated magical compass (which they took from him before sending him to get the chalices), and Gibbs' release. In return, Jack vows to give Blackbeard the chalices and lead him to the Fountain; Blackbeard agrees, and Gibbs is set free with the compass. At the Fountain, Blackbeard's crew is confronted by Barbossa and his men and they battle while Barbossa and Blackbeard fight. The Spanish suddenly arrive, intending to destroy the Fountain, believing its power an abomination against God. They crush the chalices and throw them in the swamp. When Barbossa stabs Blackbeard with a poisoned sword, Angelica pulls it out but is cut and poisoned. Jack notices Angelica is poisoned and begins frantically searching the swamp for the chalices. Barbossa obtains Blackbeard's magic sword and gains control of the ''Queen Anne's Revenge'' and her crew. Despite resistance from Blackbeard's crew, the Spanish successfully pull down a pillar, crushing the Fountain of Youth. The Spanish army leaves once the fountain is in ruins. Philip is mortally wounded, but he returns to free Syrena. She helps Jack retrieve the missing chalices and gives them to him, telling him not to waste her tear. Syrena goes back to the dying Philip. She says she can save him if he asks her to. When he asks for her forgiveness, she kisses him and takes him underwater. With Blackbeard and Angelica both nearing death, Jack retrieves the last remaining drops of water from the destroyed fountain and puts the tear in one of them. Knowing that one of them must be sacrificed, he wants Angelica to drink from the chalice containing the tear. Instead, Blackbeard drinks it, asking his daughter to save him. Angelica agrees and drinks from the second chalice. Jack is upset to lose Angelica, but reveals that he made a mistake about which chalice contained the tear. Neither of the two are happy, and they both believe Jack deliberately tricked them. Angelica's wounds are healed as the Fountain fatally consumes Blackbeard's body, killing him. Eventually, Jack and Angelica admit their love for each other, yet he distrusts her intentions (aware that she may try to avenge her father) and strands her on a [[cay]]. Now wielding Blackbeard's magical sword, Barbossa captains the ''Queen Anne's Revenge'' and returns to piracy. Jack finds Gibbs, who had used the compass to locate the ''Revenge''. He reclaims the shrunken ''Black Pearl'' and the other conquered ships in bottles, carrying them in a [[gunny sack]]. The two leave, [[Pirates of the Caribbean: Dead Men Tell No Tales|hoping to revert the ''Black Pearl'' to its original size and continue living the pirates' life]]. In a [[post-credits scene]], a [[voodoo doll]] of Jack crafted by Blackbeard washes ashore and is found by Angelica, who then smiles. ==Cast== {{main article|List of Pirates of the Caribbean characters}} {{div col|colwidth=30em}} * [[Johnny Depp]] as [[Jack Sparrow|Captain Jack Sparrow]]: Former captain of the ''[[Black Pearl]]''. * [[Penélope Cruz]] as [[Angelica (Pirates of the Caribbean)|Angelica]]: Jack's former love interest, and daughter of Blackbeard. * [[Geoffrey Rush]] as [[Hector Barbossa|Captain Hector Barbossa]]: Jack's former-rival-turned-ally, and former captain of the ''Black Pearl''. * [[Ian McShane]] as [[Blackbeard (Pirates of the Caribbean)|Blackbeard]]: Legendary pirate, and captain of the ''[[Queen Anne's Revenge]]''. * [[Kevin McNally]] as [[Joshamee Gibbs]]: Jack's friend, and former first mate. * [[Sam Claflin]] as [[Philip Swift]]: A missionary, kept prisoner aboard Blackbeard's ship. * [[Àstrid Bergès-Frisbey]] as [[Syrena (Pirates of the Caribbean)|Syrena]]: A mermaid captured by Blackbeard, and love interest of Swift. * [[Stephen Graham (actor)|Stephen Graham]] as Scrum: A self-serving member of Blackbeard's crew. * [[Greg Ellis (actor)|Greg Ellis]] as Lt. [[Bronson Webb]] as The Cook * [[Steve Evets]] as Purser * [[Derek Mears]] as the [[Master-at-arms|Master-at-Arms]] * [[DeObia Oparei]] as the [[Sailor|Gunner]] * [[Sebastian Armesto]] as [[Ferdinand VI of Spain|King Ferdinand]] of the [[Spanish Empire]] * [[Anton Lesser]] as [[John Carteret, 2nd Earl Granville|Lord John Carteret]], Viscount Carteret, Baron Carteret of Hawnes, 2nd Earl of Granville * [[Roger Allam]] as [[Prime Minister]] [[Henry Pelham]] * [[Paul Bazely]] as Salaman: An Indian crew member of the ''Queen Anne's Revenge'' {{div col end}} ==Production== ===Development=== Shortly before the premiere of ''[[Pirates of the Caribbean: At World's End|At World's End]]'', [[Jerry Bruckheimer]] stated it was the end of the trilogy, but the idea of a spin-off was still possible.{{cite web |url=http://www.heraldsun.com.au/entertainment/movies/the-pirates-treasure/story-e6frf9h6-1111113501994 |title=The pirates' treasure |first=Peter |last=Mitchell |work=[[Herald Sun]] |date=May 10, 2007 |accessdate=July 13, 2010}} After the film's successful opening weekend, [[Dick Cook]], then Chairman of the [[List of assets owned by Disney#Studio Entertainment|Walt Disney Studios]], said he was interested in a fourth installment. ''[[Los Angeles Times]]'' also reported that rights to a book were bought.{{cite news|url=http://articles.latimes.com/2007/may/29/business/fi-boxoffice29 |title=4th `Pirates' film already on horizon |work=[[Los Angeles Times]] |date=May 29, 2007 |first=Josh |last=Friedman |accessdate=July 13, 2010 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121106152812/http://articles.latimes.com/2007/may/29/business/fi-boxoffice29 |archivedate=November 6, 2012 }} [[Ted Elliott (screenwriter)|Ted Elliott]] and [[Terry Rossio]] had started working on a script in 2007, but they were interrupted by the [[2007–2008 Writers Guild of America strike]], and only resumed in mid-2008. In June 2009, Bruckheimer indicated Disney would prefer the fourth installment of ''Pirates '' to be released before ''[[The Lone Ranger (2013 film)|The Lone Ranger]]'' film, which he, Johnny Depp, [[Ted Elliott (screenwriter)|Ted Elliott]], and [[Terry Rossio]] had been working on for release on May 20, 2011. He hoped [[Gore Verbinski]] would return to direct the fourth film, as his ''[[BioShock#Canceled film|BioShock]]'' film adaptation had been put on hold.{{cite news|author=Douglas, Edward |title=Bruckheimer gives updates on Pirates & The Lone Ranger |work=ComingSoon.net |date=June 11, 2009 |url=http://www.comingsoon.net/news/movienews.php?id=56211 |accessdate=June 11, 2009 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130722105720/http://www.comingsoon.net/news/movienews.php?id=56211 |archivedate=July 22, 2013 }} As Verbinski was unavailable due to his commitment with ''[[Rango (2011 film)|Rango]]'' the same year, Bruckheimer suggested [[Rob Marshall]], who he considered a "premiere filmmaker", stating that "Every film [Marshall] made I thought was unique and different." On July 21, 2009, Marshall accepted the job, because of the "whole new story line and set of characters. It felt new, and that was important to me."{{cite news|url=http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/news/making-pirates-caribbean-186743 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/60nhBtlZu?url=http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/news/making-pirates-caribbean-186743 |archivedate=August 9, 2011 |title=The Making of 'Pirates of the Caribbean' |first=Stephen |last=Galloway |work=The Hollywood Reporter |date=May 10, 2011 |accessdate=July 29, 2011 |deadurl=yes |df= }} Marshall said the film provided him a long-awaited opportunity to work with Depp, and that his directing was helped by his experience as a choreographer—"the action sequences felt like big production numbers."{{cite news|url=http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/news/cannes-qa-pirates-caribbean-stranger-188270 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/60nhNeGVM?url=http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/news/cannes-qa-pirates-caribbean-stranger-188270 |archivedate=August 9, 2011 |title=Cannes Q&A: 'Pirates of the Caribbean: On Stranger Tides' Director Rob Marshall |first=Gregg |last=Kilday |work=The Hollywood Reporter |date=May 13, 2011 |accessdate=July 29, 2011 |deadurl=yes |df= }} On September 11, 2009, at Disney's [[D23 (Disney)|D23]] convention during a Disney event, Cook and Johnny Depp, in full Captain Jack Sparrow costume, announced that a fourth ''Pirates'' film was in development. The title was announced as ''Pirates of the Caribbean: On Stranger Tides''.{{cite news|url=http://latimesblogs.latimes.com/herocomplex/2009/09/johnny-depp-jack-sparrow-disney-costume-.html |title=Johnny Depp (in Jack Sparrow costume) surprises Disney D23 Expo audience |work=Los Angeles Times |first=Geoff |last=Boucher |date=September 11, 2009 |accessdate=July 5, 2010 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130701195008/http://herocomplex.latimes.com/uncategorized/johnny-depp-jack-sparrow-disney-costume/ |archivedate=July 1, 2013 }} Marshall visited the [[Pirates of the Caribbean (attraction)|Pirates of the Caribbean ride]] in Disneyland for inspiration, eventually paying homage with a skeleton holding a magnifying glass in Ponce de León's ship. An appearance of "Old Bill", the pirate who tries to share his rum with a cat, was also filmed but cut.{{cite video|title=Deleted/Extended Scenes|location=Pirates of the Caribbean: On Stranger Tides Blu-ray|publisher=Walt Disney Home Entertainment|year=2011}} [[Pintel and Ragetti]] were originally supposed to make an appearance, but director Rob Marshall opted out of the idea as he feared their roles would be cut.{{cite web|url=http://www.wordplayer.com/archives/rossio10.Sail.Tide.html|title=Wordplayer.com: WORDPLAY/Archives/"We Sail With the Tide" by Terry Rossio|publisher=|accessdate=October 4, 2014}} Cook resigned in September 2009 after working for Disney for over 38 years.{{cite news|url=http://articles.latimes.com/2009/sep/19/business/fi-ct-disney19 |title=Walt Disney Studios chief Dick Cook abruptly leaves the company |work=Los Angeles Times |accessdate=September 19, 2009 |first1=Dawn C. |last1=Chmielewski |first2=Claudia |last2=Eller |first3=Ben |last3=Fritz |date=September 19, 2009 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121020142943/http://articles.latimes.com/2009/sep/19/business/fi-ct-disney19 |archivedate=October 20, 2012 }} Depp's faith in ''Pirates of the Caribbean: On Stranger Tides'' was somewhat shaken after the resignation, with Depp explaining that "There's a fissure, a crack in my enthusiasm at the moment. It was all born in that office".{{cite news|url=http://latimesblogs.latimes.com/entertainmentnewsbuzz/2009/09/johnny-depp-says-hes-shocked-and-very-sad-about-dick-cooks-departure.html |title=Johnny Depp says he's 'shocked and very sad' about Dick Cook's departure |first=Claudia |last=Eller |work=Los Angeles Times |date=September 18, 2009 |accessdate=July 5, 2010 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130330141138/http://latimesblogs.latimes.com/entertainmentnewsbuzz/2009/09/johnny-depp-says-hes-shocked-and-very-sad-about-dick-cooks-departure.html |archivedate=March 30, 2013 }} Depp also explained Cook was one of the few who accepted his portrayal of Jack Sparrow: "When things went a little sideways on the [[Pirates of the Caribbean: The Curse of the Black Pearl|first ''Pirates'' movie]] and others at the studio were less than enthusiastic about my interpretation of the character, Dick was there from the first moment. He trusted me". ===Writing=== During production of ''[[Pirates of the Caribbean: Dead Man's Chest|Dead Man's Chest]]'' and ''At World's End'', writers [[Ted Elliott (screenwriter)|Ted Elliott]] and [[Terry Rossio]] discovered [[Tim Powers]]' 1987 novel ''[[On Stranger Tides]]'', which they considered a good foundation on which to base "a new chapter" in the ''Pirates'' series.{{cite news|last=Weintraub |first=Steve |title=Producer Jerry Bruckheimer On Set Interview |url=http://collider.com/jerry-bruckheimer-interview-pirates-caribbean-4-on-stranger-tides-lone-ranger/74214/ |accessdate=April 21, 2011 |newspaper=Collider |date=February 3, 2011 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110411090507/http://collider.com/jerry-bruckheimer-interview-pirates-caribbean-4-on-stranger-tides-lone-ranger/74214 |archivedate=April 11, 2011 }} Disney bought the rights to the novel in April 2007.{{cite news|url=http://latimesblogs.latimes.com/herocomplex/2009/10/surprised-author-tim-powers-finds-himself-setting-sail-with-pirates-of-the-caribbean-.html |title=Surprised author Tim Powers finds himself setting sail with 'Pirates of the Caribbean' |date=October 6, 2009 |work=Los Angeles Times |author=Boucher, Geoff |accessdate=July 5, 2010 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100809015550/http://latimesblogs.latimes.com/herocomplex/2009/10/surprised-author-tim-powers-finds-himself-setting-sail-with-pirates-of-the-caribbean-.html |archivedate=August 9, 2010 }} Rossio stated that he and Elliot had considered using Blackbeard and the Fountain of Youth in the story before reading the book, "but whenever you say those words, Powers' novel comes to mind. There was no way we could work in that field without going into territory Tim had explored." However, they denied that it would be a straight version of the novel: "Blackbeard came from the book, and in the book there is a daughter character, too. But Jack Sparrow is not in the book, nor is Barbossa. So I wouldn't call this an adaptation." Rossio declared the script was written to be a standalone film, "kind of a ''[[James Bond in film|James Bond]]'' sort of thing", instead of the "designed to be a trilogy" structure of the previous installments. They hoped to "design a story that would support new characters," as characters such as [[Will Turner]] would not return. Bruckheimer added that there was a decision to "streamline the story a little bit, make it a little simpler and not have as many characters to follow", as the number of characters and subplots in ''At World's End'' caused the film to have an unwieldy length. The duo decided to employ another sea myth alluded in the previous episodes: mermaids, which are briefly referenced in the book. The mermaids' role expanded in the script, which included a vast attack sequence. Depp was deeply involved with the story design, frequently meeting the writers to show what he was interested in doing, and in the words of Rossio, being "involved in coming up with story lines, connecting characters, creating moments that we would then fashion, shape and then go back."{{cite web|url=http://collider.com/terry-rossio-interview-pirates-caribbean-4-on-stranger-tides/74250/ |title=Screenwriter Terry Rossio On Set Interview: Pirates of the Caribbean 4: On Stranger Tides |first=Steve |last=Weintraub |date=February 3, 2011 |publisher=Collider |accessdate=July 29, 2011 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121126170214/http://collider.com/terry-rossio-interview-pirates-caribbean-4-on-stranger-tides/74250/ |archivedate=November 26, 2012 }} Among Depp's suggestions were turning Phillip into a missionary and having a Spanish contingent following the protagonists. Afterwards, Rob Marshall and executive producer John DeLuca met Rossio and Elliot, and did alterations of their own, including building the female lead. ===Casting=== {{multiple image | direction = vertical | width = 175 | footer = Top to bottom: [[Johnny Depp]], [[Geoffrey Rush]], and [[Kevin McNally]] who reprised their roles from the previous films as Captain Jack Sparrow, Captain Hector Barbossa, and Joshamee Gibbs respectively. | image1 = Johnny Depp 2, 2011.jpg | alt1 = Johnny Depp in a film premiere. | caption1 = | image2 = GeoffreyRushTIFFSept2011.jpg | alt2 = Geoffrey Rush in a festival. | caption2 = | image3 = Kevin_McNally.jpg | alt3 = Kevin McNally. | caption3 = }} Depp signed on to return as Captain Jack Sparrow in September 2008, saying that he would come back if the script was good.{{cite news|author=Graser, Marc |title=Disney, Depp return to 'Caribbean' |work=Variety |date=September 24, 2008 |url=http://www.variety.com/article/VR1117992798 |accessdate=September 25, 2008 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121104100849/http://www.variety.com/article/VR1117992798 |archivedate=November 4, 2012 }} Almost a year later, Disney announced that Depp would be paid $55.5 million for his role, realizing that without him the franchise would be "dead and buried."{{cite web|url=http://www.express.co.uk/posts/view/140454/Pirates-No-4-nets-33m-for-Johnny |title=PIRATES NO 4 NETS £33M FOR JOHNNY |publisher=''[[The Daily Express]]'' |date=November 15, 2009 |accessdate=November 15, 2009 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://archive.is/20121005034601/http://www.express.co.uk/posts/view/140454/Pirates-No-4-nets-33m-for-Johnny |archivedate=October 5, 2012 }} [[Geoffrey Rush]] expressed interest in returning to his role as Barbossa,{{cite web|url=http://moviesblog.mtv.com/2009/09/23/exclusive-geoffrey-rush-says-hes-planning-to-shoot-pirates-of-the-caribbean-on-stranger-tides-in-the-spring |title=Geoffrey Rush Says He's Planning To Shoot 'Pirates of the Caribbean: On Stranger Tides' In The Spring |publisher=''[[MTV.com]]'' |date=September 23, 2009 |first=Eric |last=Ditzian |accessdate=July 5, 2010 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121008191733/http://moviesblog.mtv.com/2009/09/23/exclusive-geoffrey-rush-says-hes-planning-to-shoot-pirates-of-the-caribbean-on-stranger-tides-in-the-spring/ |archivedate=October 8, 2012 }} and Bruckheimer later confirmed his presence. Rush was positive on Barbossa having lost a leg, as he considered the disability made him "angrier, more forceful and resilient as a character", and had to work with the stunt team for an accurate portrayal of the limp and usage of crutch, particularly during sword fighting scenes. While the production team considered a prop [[pegleg]] to be put over Rush's leg, the tight schedule caused it to be replaced with a [[Chroma key|blue sock that was replaced digitally]], with a knob on the shoe to give Rush a reference for his walk.{{cite video|people=Rob Marshall, John DeLuca|title=[[Audio commentary]] for Pirates of the Caribbean: On Stranger Tides|location=Pirates of the Caribbean: On Stranger Tides Blu-Ray|publisher=Walt Disney Home Entertainment}} Three other actors from the previous films returned, [[Kevin McNally]] as [[Joshamee Gibbs]], [[Greg Ellis (actor)|Greg Ellis]] as Lt. Theodore Groves,{{cite web|url=http://movies.ign.com/dor/objects/859550/pirates-of-the-caribbean-4/videos/pop_jb_pirates4.html |title=Pirates of the Caribbean: On Stranger Tides Movie Interview – Bruckheimer on Pirates of the Caribbean 4 |publisher=IGN |date=May 24, 2010 |accessdate=July 5, 2010 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100704183835/http://movies.ign.com/dor/objects/859550/pirates-of-the-caribbean-4/videos/pop_jb_pirates4.html |archivedate=July 4, 2010 }} and [[Damian O'Hare]] as Lt. Gilette.{{cite web|url=http://hamiltonhodell.co.uk/cv/client_damian-ohare_id_100129.htm |title=Damian O'Hare |publisher=Hamilton Hodell Talent Management |accessdate=August 6, 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120405225744/http://www.hamiltonhodell.co.uk/cv/client_damian-ohare_id_100129.htm |archivedate=April 5, 2012 }} [[Keith Richards]] also had a cameo, reprising his role as [[Captain Teague]] from ''At World's End''; he and Depp tried to persuade [[Mick Jagger]] to audition for the part of a pirate elder.{{cite web |url=http://express.co.uk/posts/view/168336/Johnny-Depp-wants-another-Rolling-Stone-to-join-Pirates-of-the-Caribbean- |work=[[The Daily Express]] |title=Johnny Depp Wants Another Rolling Stone to Join Pirates of the Caribbean|date=April 10, 2010 |accessdate=July 5, 2010}} Previous cast members [[Orlando Bloom]] and [[Keira Knightley]] stated that they would not reprise their roles, as they wanted to be involved in different films. They both thought the storyline involving their characters had gone as far as it could.{{cite web |url=http://www.independent.ie/entertainment/film-cinema/three-pirates-enough-for-keira-2107349.html |title=Three Pirates enough for Keira |work=[[The Independent]] |date=March 22, 2010 |accessdate=July 5, 2010}}{{cite web|url=http://moviesblog.mtv.com/2010/01/26/orlando-bloom-wont-return-for-pirates-of-the-caribbean-on-stranger-tides |title=Orlando Bloom Won't Return For 'Pirates Of The Caribbean: On Stranger Tides' |publisher=''[[MTV.com]]'' |date=January 26, 2010 |accessdate=July 5, 2010 |first=Josh |last=Wigler |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130120113955/http://moviesblog.mtv.com/2010/01/26/orlando-bloom-wont-return-for-pirates-of-the-caribbean-on-stranger-tides/ |archivedate=January 20, 2013 }}{{cite web|url=http://www.collider.com/2010/02/20/johnny-depp-provides-updates-on-dark-shadows-the-tourist-and-pirates-of-the-caribbean-on-stranger-tides |title=Johnny Depp Provides Updates on Dark Shadows, The Tourist and Pirates of the Caribbean: On Stranger Tides |publisher=''Collider.com'' |first=Steve |last=Weintraub |date=February 20, 2010 |accessdate=July 5, 2010 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100701101113/http://www.collider.com/2010/02/20/johnny-depp-provides-updates-on-dark-shadows-the-tourist-and-pirates-of-the-caribbean-on-stranger-tides |archivedate=July 1, 2010 }} On August 1, 2009, [[Bill Nighy]] expressed his desire to return as Davy Jones, who died in the [[Pirates of the Caribbean: At World's End|previous film,]] saying the possibility to resurrect the character, but at the end, his inclusion was scrapped.{{cite web|url=http://www.mtv.com/news/2431244/bill-nighy-eager-to-sail-again-for-pirates-of-the-caribbean-4/ |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2017-03-03 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160805101046/http://www.mtv.com/news/2431244/bill-nighy-eager-to-sail-again-for-pirates-of-the-caribbean-4/ |archivedate=August 5, 2016 }}{{cite web|url=http://www.blastr.com/2009/10/is_pirates_of_the_caribbe.php |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2017-03-03 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20161118144334/http://www.blastr.com/2009/10/is_pirates_of_the_caribbe.php |archivedate=November 18, 2016 }} On February 5, 2010, [[Mackenzie Crook]] also announced he would not be reprising his role of [[Pintel and Ragetti|Ragetti]], stating, "They haven't asked me. But actually I don't mind that at all. I'm a fan of the first one especially and I think the trilogy we've made is great. I'd almost like them to leave it there."{{cite news|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/arts-entertainment/theatre-dance/features/mackenzie-crook-more-than-just-the-office-boy-1889475.html |title=Mackenzie Crook: More than just the Office boy |work=[[The Independent]] |date=February 5, 2010 |first=Alice |last=Jones |accessdate=July 5, 2010 |location=London |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121224194453/http://www.independent.co.uk/arts-entertainment/theatre-dance/features/mackenzie-crook-more-than-just-the-office-boy-1889475.html |archivedate=December 24, 2012 }} New cast members include [[Ian McShane]], who plays the notorious pirate and primary antagonist of the film, [[Blackbeard]], and [[Penélope Cruz]], who plays Angelica, Jack Sparrow's love interest.{{cite web |url=http://moviesblog.mtv.com/2010/03/22/pirates-4-producer-jerry-bruckheimer-confirms-geoffrey-rush-return-penelope-cruz-as-blackbeards-daughter |title=Exclusive: Penelope Cruz To Play Johnny Depp's Love Interest In New 'Pirates' |author=Ditzian, Eric |date=March 19, 2010 |publisher=''MTV Movie News'' |accessdate=March 19, 2010 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130120044438/http://moviesblog.mtv.com/2010/03/22/pirates-4-producer-jerry-bruckheimer-confirms-geoffrey-rush-return-penelope-cruz-as-blackbeards-daughter/ |archivedate=January 20, 2013 |df=mdy-all }} According to Marshall, McShane was chosen because "he can play something evil but there's always humor behind it as well" and the actor accepted the job due to both the "very funny and charming" script and the opportunity to work with Marshall. The beard took one hour and a half to get applied, and McShane likened the character's costume to "a real [[outlaw motorcycle club|biker]] pirate—it's all black leather.”{{cite web|url=http://www.totalfilm.com/news/ian-mcshane-talks-pirates-4 |title=Ian McShane talks Pirates 4 |work=[[Total Film]] |date=April 11, 2011 |accessdate=January 5, 2012 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131029235623/http://www.totalfilm.com/news/ian-mcshane-talks-pirates-4 |archivedate=October 29, 2013 }} Marshall said Cruz was the only actress considered for the role, as she fit the description as "an actress who could not only go toe to toe with Johnny and match him, but also needed to be all the things that Jack Sparrow is in a way. She needed to be funny and clever and smart and crafty and beautiful", and invited her for the role as they wrapped the production of ''[[Nine (2009 live-action film)|Nine]]''. The actress spent two months working out and learning fencing for the role.{{Cite news|title=La armada invencible española viaja a 'Piratas del Caribe 4' |work=[[El País]] |date=June 29, 2010 |url=http://blogs.elpais.com/version-muy-original/2010/06/la-armada-invencible-espa%C3%B1ola-viaja-a-piratas-del-caribe-4.html |accessdate=July 4, 2010 |language=Spanish |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120112233042/http://blogs.elpais.com/version-muy-original/2010/06/la-armada-invencible-espa%C3%B1ola-viaja-a-piratas-del-caribe-4.html |archivedate=January 12, 2012 }} During filming, Cruz discovered she was pregnant, leading the costume department to redesign her wardrobe to be more elastic, and the producers to hire her sister [[Mónica Cruz]] to double for Penélope in risky scenes.{{cite web|url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/tvshowbiz/article-1327345/Pregnant-Penelope-Cruz-leaves-London-LOT-luggage.html |title=Packing for two, Penelope? Pregnant star leaves London with a LOT of luggage |work=[[The Daily Mail]] |date=November 7, 2010 |accessdate=January 12, 2012 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://archive.is/20120630060728/http://www.dailymail.co.uk/tvshowbiz/article-1327345/Pregnant-Penelope-Cruz-leaves-London-LOT-luggage.html |archivedate=June 30, 2012 }} Depp recommended [[Stephen Graham (actor)|Stephen Graham]], who worked with him in ''[[Public Enemies (2009 film)|Public Enemies]]'', to play Scrum, a Machiavellian pirate and sidekick to Jack Sparrow,{{cite news|url=http://www.variety.com/article/VR1118020143 |title=Graham sails with 'Pirates 4' crew |work=Variety |date=June 3, 2010 |first=Dave |last=McNary |accessdate=July 5, 2010 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121108040758/http://www.variety.com/article/VR1118020143 |archivedate=November 8, 2012 }}Shennan, Paddy. [http://www.liverpoolecho.co.uk/liverpool-life/liverpool-lifestyle/2010/10/22/this-is-england-star-stephen-graham-on-why-he-s-celebrating-halloween-in-liverpool-this-year-100252-27523066/#ixzz1363tpfy6 "This is England star Stephen Graham on why he's celebrating Halloween in Liverpool this year"] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120119101046/http://www.liverpoolecho.co.uk/liverpool-life/liverpool-lifestyle/2010/10/22/this-is-england-star-stephen-graham-on-why-he-s-celebrating-halloween-in-liverpool-this-year-100252-27523066/ |date=January 19, 2012 }} ''[[Liverpool Echo]]'' (October 22, 2010). Retrieved 2011-03-15. and [[Richard Griffiths]] for the role of [[George II of Great Britain|King George II]], as Depp was a fan of Griffiths' work on ''[[Withnail and I]]''. [[Sam Claflin]], a recent drama school graduate with television experience, was chosen to play the missionary Philip,{{cite press release|title=Sam Claflin Added to Cast of Walt Disney Pictures'/Jerry Bruckheimer Films' Epic Adventure ''Pirates of the Caribbean: On Stranger Tides'' |publisher=Walt Disney Pictures |url=http://www.slashfilm.com/sam-claflin-joins-pirates-of-the-caribbean-on-stranger-tides/ |date=April 16, 2010 |accessdate=July 5, 2010 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://archive.is/20121111053714/http://www.slashfilm.com/sam-claflin-joins-pirates-of-the-caribbean-on-stranger-tides/ |archivedate=November 11, 2012 }} and British actor [[Paul Bazely]] also joined the cast.{{cite web|url=http://disneyparks.disney.go.com/blog/2010/09/new-pirates-of-the-caribbean-on-stranger-tides-cast-members-find-inspiration-at-disneyland-park/ |title=New 'Pirates of the Caribbean: On Stranger Tides' Cast Members Find Inspiration at Disneyland Park |first=George |last=Savvas |publisher=[[Walt Disney Parks and Resorts]] |date=May 25, 2010 |accessdate=September 3, 2010 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130121174604/http://disneyparks.disney.go.com/blog/2010/09/new-pirates-of-the-caribbean-on-stranger-tides-cast-members-find-inspiration-at-disneyland-park/ |archivedate=January 21, 2013 }} Spanish news website ''[[El Pais]]'' reported that the film had four Spanish actors: Cruz, Bergès-Frisbey, Óscar Jaenada, and [[Juan Carlos Vellido]].{{cite web|url=http://www.20minutos.es/noticia/751909/3/espanoles/piratas/caribe |title=Cuatro españoles en 'Piratas del Caribe 4 |first=Carles |last=Rull |date=June 30, 2010 |work=[[20 minutos]] |publisher=Multiprensa & Mas S.L. |accessdate=January 27, 2011 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20101106000002/http://www.20minutos.es/noticia/751909/3/espanoles/piratas/caribe/ |archivedate=November 6, 2010 }} Jaenada was picked for both his work in ''[[The Losers (film)|The Losers]]'' and a recommendation by Cruz.{{Cite news|title=Óscar Jaenada, a punto de ser un 'pirata del Caribe' |work=[[El Periódico de Catalunya]] |date=June 10, 2011 |url=http://www2.elperiodico.es/default.asp?idpublicacio_PK=46&idioma=CAS&idnoticia_PK=712329&idseccio_PK=1028&h=100510 |accessdate=January 12, 2012 |language=Spanish |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120120103357/http://www2.elperiodico.es/default.asp?idpublicacio_PK=46&idioma=CAS&idnoticia_PK=712329&idseccio_PK=1028&h=100510 |archivedate=January 20, 2012 }} Casting for mermaids required the actresses to have natural breasts—no [[Breast implant|implants]]. As Bruckheimer explained to ''[[Entertainment Weekly|EW]]'', "I don't think they had breast augmentation in the 1700s, [...] So it's natural for casting people to say, 'We want real people.'"{{cite news|url=http://insidemovies.ew.com/2011/01/26/pirates-of-the-caribbean-mermaids-breast |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/60niFbdyd?url=http://insidemovies.ew.com/2011/01/26/pirates-of-the-caribbean-mermaids-breast |archivedate=August 9, 2011 |title='Pirates of the Caribbean: On Stranger Tides': Jerry Bruckheimer explains why you need real breasts to play a mermaid |last=Collis |first=Clark |date=January 26, 2011 |work=[[Entertainment Weekly]] |accessdate=January 27, 2011 |deadurl=yes |df= }} Marshall invited Spanish-French actress [[Àstrid Bergès-Frisbey]] to play Syrena after seeing her in a French magazine article on up-and-coming actresses.{{cite video|title=Legends of On Stranger Tides|location=Pirates of the Caribbean: On Stranger Tides Blu-ray|publisher=Walt Disney Home Entertainment|year=2011}} Bergès-Frisbey had to take lessons of English, swimming and breath control for the role.{{cite web|last=Singer |first=Leigh |url=http://movies.ign.com/articles/116/1168491p1.html |title=Pirates of the Caribbean: Astrid Berges-Frisbey Interview |publisher=IGN |date=May 17, 2011 |accessdate=July 23, 2011 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110820012331/http://movies.ign.com/articles/116/1168491p1.html |archivedate=August 20, 2011 }} The rest of the mermaid portrayers, such as Australian supermodel [[Gemma Ward]],{{cite web|url=http://www.couriermail.com.au/entertainment/pirate-tale-for-gemma-ward/story-e6freq7f-1225879013948 |author=JMO and Elle |title=Pirate tale for Gemma Ward |work=[[The Sunday Telegraph]] |date=June 13, 2010 |accessdate=July 5, 2010 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110812095411/http://www.couriermail.com.au/entertainment/pirate-tale-for-gemma-ward/story-e6freq7f-1225879013948 |archivedate=August 12, 2011 }} were chosen for having "exotic sense, an otherworldly sensibility, but also under those layers a deadly quality", according to Marshall, and had to take swimming lessons to learn movements such as the [[butterfly stroke|dolphin]] and [[eggbeater kick]]s. ===Filming=== [[Principal photography]] began on June 14, 2010, in Hawaii.{{cite web |url=https://www.twitter.com/BruckheimerJB/status/16181655179 |author=[[Jerry Bruckheimer|Bruckheimer, Jerry]] |title=Announcement of initial shooting |publisher=''Twitter'' |date=June 14, 2010 |accessdate=July 5, 2010}} Filming was moved to California in August 2010,{{cite web|url=http://www.featurefilmcasting.com/2010/06/walt-disney-pictures-open-casting-call.html |title=Disney open casting calls for 'Pirates of the Caribbean: On Stranger Tides' in Los Angeles |publisher=''Disney Feature Film Casting'' |date=July 5, 2010 |accessdate=July 5, 2010 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121028011243/http://www.featurefilmcasting.com/2010/06/walt-disney-pictures-open-casting-call.html |archivedate=October 28, 2012 }} primarily at the [[Long Beach, California|Long Beach]] shore and a recreation of Whitecap Bay done in the [[Universal Studios]] backlot, as the original Hawaiian location on [[Halona Blowhole#Halona Cove|Halona Cove]] was plagued with strong tides. After a brief shoot in [[Puerto Rico]], with locations in both [[Isla Palominos (Puerto Rico)|Palomino Island]] and the [[Castillo de San Cristóbal (Puerto Rico)|Fort of San Cristóbal]] in [[San Juan, Puerto Rico|San Juan]],{{cite news |url=http://articles.latimes.com/2011/mar/09/business/la-fi-ct-onlocation-20110305 |title=Puerto Rico boosts tax incentives for bigger Hollywood role |date=March 9, 2011 |accessdate=January 11, 2012 |author=Verrier, Richard |work=Los Angeles Times |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121015172529/http://articles.latimes.com/2011/mar/09/business/la-fi-ct-onlocation-20110305 |archivedate=October 15, 2012 }} production moved to the United Kingdom in September, where principal photography wrapped on November 18 after 106 days of shooting. Locations included [[Hampton Court Palace]] in London, [[Knole House]] in [[Kent]], and [[Old Royal Naval College]] at [[Greenwich]]. Interiors were shot at London's [[Pinewood Studios]], and a replica of an 18th-century London street was built on the backlot alongside the soundstages.{{cite web|url=http://www.pinewoodgroup.com/2010/08/pirates |title=New Pirates of the Caribbean epic to film |publisher=''Pinewood Studios Group'' |date=August 2, 2010 |accessdate=August 26, 2010 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100817224247/http://www.pinewoodgroup.com/2010/08/pirates/ |archivedate=August 17, 2010 }} The producers also considered using [[New Orleans]] as a location.{{cite web|url=http://www.nola.com/movies/index.ssf/2010/06/pirates_of_the_caribbean_spoke.html |first=Mike |last=Scott |work=[[The Times-Picayune]] |title='Pirates of the Caribbean' spokesman lets the wind out of the sails of New Orleans fans |date=June 10, 2010 |accessdate=July 5, 2010 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130527163757/http://www.nola.com/movies/index.ssf/2010/06/pirates_of_the_caribbean_spoke.html |archivedate=May 27, 2013 }} In October, security was breached at the UK site when a [[celebrity impersonator]] gained access to filming at the Old Royal Naval College by dressing up as Captain Jack.Smart, Gordon. [http://www.thesun.co.uk/sol/homepage/showbiz/bizarre/3172487/Impersonator-gets-on-to-Pirates-of-the-Caribbean-4-set-dressed-as-Captain-Jack.html "Impersonator gets on to Pirates of the Caribbean 4 set dressed as Captain Jack"] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20131210032354/http://www.thesun.co.uk/sol/homepage/showbiz/bizarre/3172487/Impersonator-gets-on-to-Pirates-of-the-Caribbean-4-set-dressed-as-Captain-Jack.html |date=December 10, 2013 }}. ''[[The Sun (United Kingdom)|The Sun]]''. Retrieved October 9, 2010. After the joint production of ''Dead Man's Chest'' and ''At World's End'' cost over $300 million, Disney decided to give a lower budget to the fourth installment.{{Cite news|last=Stewart |first=Andrew |title=Fourth try aims to stir high 'Tides' at B.O. |date=May 19, 2011 |work=Variety |url=http://www.variety.com/article/VR1118037362 |accessdate=May 20, 2011 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110523102701/http://www.variety.com/article/VR1118037362 |archivedate=May 23, 2011 }} Many costs had to be cut, including moving primary production to Hawaii and London, where tax credits are more favorable, and having a shorter shooting schedule and fewer scenes featuring special effects compared to ''At World's End''.{{cite news|url=http://articles.latimes.com/2010/may/03/business/la-fi-ct-bruckheimer-20100427 |title=Not even Bruckheimer movies can escape budget cuts |date=May 3, 2010 |accessdate=July 5, 2010 |author1=Eller, Claudia |author2=Chmielewski, Dawn C. |work=Los Angeles Times |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121105020450/http://articles.latimes.com/2010/may/03/business/la-fi-ct-bruckheimer-20100427 |archivedate=November 5, 2012 }} The tighter schedule—according to Bruckheimer, "We had a 22-week post, and for a picture like this, with almost 1,200 visual effects shots, it's usually 40 weeks"—meant that Marshall supervised editing of sequences during filming. The British financial statements of the film revealed total expenditures of £240.7 million ($410.6 million) by 2013, with Disney receiving a rebate of $32.1 million from the British government, making ''Pirates of the Caribbean: On Stranger Tides'' the [[List of most expensive films|most expensive film ever made]] to date. Bruckheimer said the decision to film in 3D was made due to its being "immersive filmmaking; I think it makes you part of the actual filming because you're part of the screen." Bruckheimer described it as the first major "exterior movie" to be shot in 3D, as ''[[Avatar (2009 film)|Avatar]]'' was mostly done in sound stages. At first Marshall was not much interested in 3D, but the director eventually considered it a film that could benefit from the format. "You are on an adventure and with the 3D experience you are inside that adventure." While the original plan was to add 3D effects during post-production, the decision was made to shoot digitally with 3D cameras. Only one sequence was shot conventionally and needed a [[2D to 3D conversion|3D conversion]]. The cameras were improved versions of the ones [[James Cameron]] developed for ''Avatar'', which were made more compact for extra mobility. This meant the cameras could be brought into locations such as the Hawaiian jungle.{{cite news|url=http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/news/new-3d-technology-pirates-caribbean-191030 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/60nhmJU8j?url=http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/news/new-3d-technology-pirates-caribbean-191030 |archivedate=August 9, 2011 |title=The New 3D Technology Behind 'Pirates of the Caribbean' |date=May 22, 2011 |accessdate=July 29, 2011 |author=Giardina, Carolyn |work=The Hollywood Reporter |deadurl=yes |df= }} ''Queen Anne's Revenge'' was built atop ''Sunset'', the same ship used to depict ''Black Pearl'' in previous installments. In February 2010, ''Sunset'' was sailed from Long Beach to a shipyard in Hawaii for the reforms, where a big concern was to make it imposing, with three stories, without sacrificing actual [[seakeeping]]. Given Blackbeard was meant to be the meanest pirate to appear in the series, the look for ''Queen Anne's Revenge'' was ominous, with sails dyed blood red, various elements on fire, and a decoration based on skulls and bones (drawing inspiration from the [[Sedlec Ossuary]] in Czech Republic). Damage from cannon fire was also added to show that "not only Blackbeard was a dying man, but his ship is also a dying ship". The ship's [[figurehead]] also drew inspiration from Blackbeard's [[Jolly Roger|pirate flag]].{{cite video|title=Last Sail/First Voyage|location=Pirates of the Caribbean: On Stranger Tides Blu-ray|publisher=Walt Disney Home Entertainment|year=2011}} The replica ship {{HMS|Surprise|replica ship|6}} was used for Barbossa's ship, HMS ''Providence'',{{cite book|title=The Art of Pirates of the Caribbean: On Stranger Tides|first=Michael|last=Singer|publisher=Disney Editions|year=2011|ISBN=1-4231-3946-1}} and all the scenes aboard ''Providence'' were shot on the Long Beach shore as ''Surprise'' could not be sailed to Hawaii. Over 50 designs were considered for the Fountain of Youth, with the final one representing a temple built by an ancient civilization around the Fountain, which itself was located in a round rocky structure to represent "the circle of life". The locations leading up to the Fountain were shot in the Hawaiian islands of [[Kauai]] and [[Oahu]], but the Fountain itself was built at the [[007 Stage]] on Pinewood.{{cite video|title=In Search of the Fountain|location=Pirates of the Caribbean: On Stranger Tides Blu-ray|publisher=Walt Disney Home Entertainment|year=2011}} ===Effects=== ''On Stranger Tides'' employed 1,112 shots of [[computer-generated imagery]],{{cite news|url=http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/news/making-pirates-caribbean-186743?page=2 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/60qdn2Mbb?url=http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/news/making-pirates-caribbean-186743?page=2 |archivedate=August 11, 2011 |page=2 |title=The Making of 'Pirates of the Caribbean' |first=Stephen |last=Galloway |work=The Hollywood Reporter |date=May 10, 2011 |accessdate=July 29, 2011 |deadurl=yes |df= }} which were done by ten visual effects companies.{{cite web|url=http://www.cinefex.com/upcomingfilms/upcoming.php?id=163 |title=Pirates of the Caribbean: On Stranger Tides |publisher=Cinefex |accessdate=July 29, 2011 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121116105805/http://www.cinefex.com/upcomingfilms/upcoming.php?id=163 |archivedate=November 16, 2012 }} [[Cinesite]] visual effects supervisor Simon Stanley-Clamp claimed that the most difficult part was doing the effects in 3D: "[[Rotoscoping]] is tricky. Cleaning up plates is double the work, and [[Match moving|tracking]] has to be spot on." The lead companies, with over 300 effects each, were [[Industrial Light & Magic]]—responsible for, among others, the mermaids and most water effects{{cite web|url=http://www.awn.com/articles/visual-effects/splash-mermaids-fourth-pirates/page/2%2C1 |title=A Splash of Mermaids for Fourth Pirates |publisher=[[Animation World Network]] |date=May 24, 2011 |first=Bill |last=Desowitz |accessdate=July 29, 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121017234231/http://www.awn.com/articles/visual-effects/splash-mermaids-fourth-pirates/page/2%2C1 |archivedate=October 17, 2012 }}—and [[Moving Picture Company]], who created digital ships and environment extensions, such as changing weather and designing cliffs and waterfalls.{{cite web|url=http://www.fxguide.com/featured/mpcs-pirates-and-their-ships-in-stranger-tides/ |title=MPC's pirates & their ships sail on Stranger Tides |publisher=fxguide |date=June 14, 2011 |first=Ian |last=Failes |accessdate=July 29, 2011 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120923135045/http://www.fxguide.com/featured/mpcs-pirates-and-their-ships-in-stranger-tides/ |archivedate=September 23, 2012 }} Filming the mermaids involved eight model-actresses, who portrayed them outside the water, as well as 22 [[synchronized swimming]] athletes and a group of stuntwomen, both of whom wore [[motion capture]] suits to be later replaced by digital mermaids. Mermaid corpses were depicted by plaster models.{{cite web|url=http://www.festival-cannes.fr/assets/Image/Direct/040664.pdf |title=Pirates of the Caribbean: On Stranger Tides production notes |format=PDF |publisher=[[Walt Disney Pictures]] |accessdate=July 29, 2011 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121212060008/http://www.festival-cannes.fr/assets/Image/Direct/040664.pdf |archivedate=December 12, 2012 }}{{cite video|title=Under the Scene: Bringing Mermaids to Life|location=Pirates of the Caribbean: On Stranger Tides Blu-ray|publisher=Walt Disney Home Entertainment|year=2011}} The design tried to avoid the traditional representations of mermaids in paintings and literature, instead going for a scaly body with a translucent membrane inspired by both jellyfish and the fabric employed in [[ballet tutu]]s. To make the mermaids more menacing underwater, the faces of the actresses had some digital touch-ups on the underwater scenes, adding sharper teeth and a shimmery fish scale quality on the skin.{{cite web|url=http://www.dailyblam.com/news/2011/09/16/interview-vfx-art-director-aaron-mcbride-discusses-working-on-the-mermaid-sequence-f |title=INTERVIEW: PIRATES OF THE CARIBBEAN VFX Art Director Aaron McBride on Creating the Film's Mermaids |publisher=The Daily BLAM! |date=September 16, 2011 |first=Kimberly |last=Houston |accessdate=September 22, 2011 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110928004547/http://www.dailyblam.com/news/2011/09/16/interview-vfx-art-director-aaron-mcbride-discusses-working-on-the-mermaid-sequence-f |archivedate=September 28, 2011 }} ILM also handled Blackbeard's death, where Ian McShane's actual performance was covered by digital doubles which turned him into a "boiling mass of blood and clothing", and a hurricane-like formation that represented "the waters of the Fountain taking his life". Cinesite handled the recreation of London and Barbossa's peg leg,{{cite web|url=http://magazine.creativecow.net/article/a-look-at-vfx-in-pirates-of-the-caribbean-on-stranger-tides |title=Behind the Lens: A look at VFX in Pirates of the Caribbean: On Stranger Tides |publisher=Creative COW Magazine |date=June 29, 2011 |first=Debra |last=Kaufman |accessdate=July 29, 2011 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110812050038/http://magazine.creativecow.net/article/a-look-at-vfx-in-pirates-of-the-caribbean-on-stranger-tides |archivedate=August 12, 2011 }} CIS Hollywood did 3D corrections and minor shots, and [[Method Studios]] created [[matte painting]]s.{{cite web|url=http://www.awn.com/news/cg/cis-hollywood-and-method-studios-discuss-stranger-tides |title=CIS Hollywood and Method Studios Discuss On Stranger Tides |publisher=[[Animation World Network]] |date=May 26, 2011 |first=Bill |last=Desowitz |accessdate=July 29, 2011 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121017234314/http://www.awn.com/news/cg/cis-hollywood-and-method-studios-discuss-stranger-tides |archivedate=October 17, 2012 }} ===Music=== {{Main article|Pirates of the Caribbean: On Stranger Tides (soundtrack)}} The [[Film score|film's score]] was written by [[Hans Zimmer]], who had worked in all of the previous entries in the franchise; being the main composer for the second and third installments. Zimmer said that he tried to incorporate a rock n' roll sound, as he felt "pirates were the rock 'n' rollers of many, many years ago",{{cite web|url=http://www.movieweb.com/movie/pirates-of-the-caribbean-on-stranger-tides/hans-zimmer-interview |title=Pirates of the Caribbean: On Stranger Tides: Hans Zimmer Interview |date=May 5, 2011 |publisher=MovieWeb |accessdate=August 6, 2011 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120930073953/http://www.movieweb.com/movie/pirates-of-the-caribbean-on-stranger-tides/hans-zimmer-interview |archivedate=September 30, 2012 }} and Spanish elements, which led to a collaboration with Mexican guitarists [[Rodrigo y Gabriela]] and a [[tango music|tango]] song written by Penélope Cruz's brother Eduardo.{{cite web|url=http://www.filmmusicmag.com/?p=7890 |title=Audio: On The Score With Hans Zimmer |first=Daniel |last=Schweiger |date=May 6, 2011 |publisher=Film Music Magazine |accessdate=August 7, 2011 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130719020043/http://www.filmmusicmag.com/?p=7890 |archivedate=July 19, 2013 }} American composer [[Eric Whitacre]] contributed several choir-based cues,[[Eric Whitacre|Whitacre, Eric]]. [http://ericwhitacre.com/blog/pirates-iv "Pirates IV! – Blog"] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120912025746/http://ericwhitacre.com/blog/pirates-iv |date=September 12, 2012 }}. (January 25, 2011) EricWhitacre.com Retrieved 2011-03-15. as well as regular assistant [[Geoff Zanelli]].{{cite press release|url=http://www.prnewswire.com/news-releases/walt-disney-pictures-and-jerry-bruckheimer-films-pirates-of-the-caribbean-on-stranger-tides-soundtrack-sets-sail-with-oscar-winning-composer-hans-zimmer-at-the-helm-with-acclaimed-guitar-duo-rodrigo-y-gabriela-121486304.html |title=Walt Disney Pictures and Jerry Bruckheimer Films' "Pirates of the Caribbean: On Stranger Tides" Soundtrack Sets Sail With Oscar®-Winning Composer Hans Zimmer at the Helm With Acclaimed Guitar Duo Rodrigo y Gabriela |publisher=[[Walt Disney Records]] |date=May 2, 2011 |accessdate=July 29, 2011 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121028011249/http://www.prnewswire.com/news-releases/walt-disney-pictures-and-jerry-bruckheimer-films-pirates-of-the-caribbean-on-stranger-tides-soundtrack-sets-sail-with-oscar-winning-composer-hans-zimmer-at-the-helm-with-acclaimed-guitar-duo-rodrigo-y-gabriela-121486304.html |archivedate=October 28, 2012 }} ==Release== [[File:Penélope Cruz and Johnny Depp - Cannes 2011.jpg|thumb|upright|right|[[Penélope Cruz]] and [[Johnny Depp]] promoting the film at the [[2011 Cannes Film Festival]].|alt=On a staircase with a red carpet stand both a man wearing glasses and a white jacket atop a black business suit, and a woman wearing a blue dress with transparencies.]] On January 6, 2010, Disney announced that the film would be released in the United States and Canada on May 20, 2011, following [[Columbia Pictures]]' announcement of a delay in the [[The Amazing Spider-Man (2012 film)|''Spider-Man'' reboot]] and [[Paramount Pictures]] slating ''[[Thor (film)|Thor]]'' for May 6, 2011.{{cite news|url=http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/news/spider-man-4-release-date-19222 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/60nhoz1ga?url=http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/news/spider-man-4-release-date-19222 |archivedate=August 9, 2011 |title='Spider-Man 4' release date squeezed |first=Carl |last=DiOrio |date=January 6, 2010 |work=The Hollywood Reporter |accessdate=July 5, 2010 |deadurl=yes |df= }} The film was released in [[IMAX 3D]], as well as traditional 2D and [[IMAX]] format,{{cite web |url=http://www.imax.com/screening/news/IMAX_and_Disney_3_Pic_Deal |title=IMAX and Disney Sign New 3 Picture Deal|publisher=''[[IMAX Corporation]]'' |date=June 23, 2010 |accessdate=July 5, 2010 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100705085514/http://www.imax.com/screening/news/IMAX_and_Disney_3_Pic_Deal |archivedate=July 5, 2010}}[http://www.comingsoon.net/news/movienews.php?id=70692 "Pirates of the Caribbean Teaser Trailer with TRON: Legacy"] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20121012001441/http://www.comingsoon.net/news/movienews.php?id=70692 |date=October 12, 2012 }}. ''ComingSoon.net''. Retrieved March 15, 2011. with Dolby [[7.1 surround sound]].{{cite news|title='Pirates of the Caribbean,' 'Kung Fu Panda 2' to Use Dolby 7.1 Surround Sound |url=http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/news/pirates-caribbean-kung-fu-panda-171990 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/60nhqvkjw?url=http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/news/pirates-caribbean-kung-fu-panda-171990 |archivedate=August 9, 2011 |first=Carolyn |last=Giardina |work=The Hollywood Reporter |date=March 28, 2011 |accessdate=March 29, 2011 |deadurl=yes |df= }} This film was also the first film to be released in the [[4DX]] motion theaters in [[Mexico]] and in the [[Western Hemisphere]], featuring strobe lights, tilting seats, blowing wind and fog and odor effects.{{cite news|last=García Sánchez |first=Rubén |title=Cinépolis presenta sus salas más costosas |url=http://eleconomista.com.mx/entretenimiento/2011/06/02/cinepolis-presenta-sus-salas-mas-costosas |accessdate=April 16, 2013 |newspaper=El Economista |date=June 2, 2011 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110826071314/http://eleconomista.com.mx/entretenimiento/2011/06/02/cinepolis-presenta-sus-salas-mas-costosas |archivedate=August 26, 2011 }} It is available exclusively at select [[Cinépolis]] cinemas.{{cite news|last=Hecht |first=John |title=Mexico's Cinepolis Going First-class in the U.S. |url=http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/news/mexicos-cinepolis-going-first-class-208028 |accessdate=June 1, 2013 |newspaper=The Hollywood Reporter |date=July 18, 2011 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131120062723/http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/news/mexicos-cinepolis-going-first-class-208028 |archivedate=November 20, 2013 }} The [[Premiere|world premiere]] of ''On Stranger Tides'' was on May 7, 2011, at a premium ticket screening at [[Disneyland]] in [[Anaheim, California]], home of the original ''[[Pirates of the Caribbean (attraction)|Pirates of the Caribbean]]'' ride that inspired the film series. Many of the film's stars were in attendance. Two other early screenings followed, one in Moscow on May 11,{{cite news|url=http://www.variety.com/article/VR1118035965 |title='Pirates' set for first Russian bow |first=Marc |last=Graser |work=Variety |date=April 27, 2011 |accessdate=July 29, 2011 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20111223213413/http://www.variety.com/article/VR1118035965 |archivedate=December 23, 2011 }} and another during the [[Cannes International Film Festival]] on May 14.{{cite news|last=Breznican |first=Anthony |title=Johnny Depp's 'Pirates 4' headed for Cannes Film Festival |url=http://insidemovies.ew.com/2011/04/13/johnny-depps-pirates-4-headed-for-cannes-film-festival/ |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/60niMcvya?url=http://insidemovies.ew.com/2011/04/13/johnny-depps-pirates-4-headed-for-cannes-film-festival |archivedate=August 9, 2011 |accessdate=April 21, 2011 |newspaper=Entertainment Weekly |date=April 13, 2011 |deadurl=yes |df= }} The international release dates fell within May 18 and 20, with opening dates in the United Kingdom on May 18, in Australia on May 19, and in North America on May 20.{{cite web|title=Pirates of the Caribbean: On Stranger Tides |url=http://movies.ign.com/objects/859/859550.html |publisher=IGN |accessdate=April 25, |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/60niPKdz8?url=http://insidemovies.ew.com/2011/05/22/box-office-report-pirates-caribbean-stranger-tides/ |title=Box office report: 'Pirates of the Caribbean' $260.4 Million Overseas, Largest Offshore Debut Ever |first=Frank |last=Segers |work=The Hollywood Reporter |date=May 22, 2011 |accessdate=May 22, 2011 |deadurl=yes |df= }} ===Promotion=== Disney's marketing president, [[MT Carney]], said that the film's advertising campaign was intended "to remind people of why they fell in love with Jack Sparrow in the first place and also introduce new elements in a way that was elegant". [[Sony Pictures]]' former marketing president, Valerie Van Galder, was hired as a consultant.{{cite news|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/2010/09/08/us-disney-idUSTRE6870ON20100908 |first=Kim advertising|spot]] on February 2011, which was later released online in an extended version;{{cite news|last=Lichtig |first=Max |title='Pirates of the Caribbean: On Stranger Tides' Super Bowl Spot |url=http://collider.com/pirates-caribbean-on-stranger-tides-super-bowl-ad/74930/ |accessdate=April 21, 2011 |publisher=Collider |date=February 6, 2011 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120902032554/http://collider.com/pirates-caribbean-on-stranger-tides-super-bowl-ad/74930 |archivedate=September 2, 2012 }} and a final trailer in March that
